revised_title: Ritualization of Land-Diving Ceremony in Pentecost, New Hebrides
tldr: The land-diving ceremony in Pentecost, New Hebrides, is a ritual where men jump off a 80-feet high tower using vines tied to their ankles to slow their fall. The author discusses the cultural significance of this ritual and its possible origins as a rite of passage. The ceremony involves villagers from several northern villages on Pentecost Island, and people of all ages participate, even elders.
scientific_discipline: Social Sciences, Art, and Humanities > Anthropology
